thread.title: Bali ash cloud: What happens when your flight is cancelled?
thread.title_full: Bali ash cloud: What happens when your flight is cancelled?

author: Rowena Ryan
title: Bali ash cloud: What happens when your flight is cancelled?
text:
A VOLCANIC ash cloud near Bali has caused havoc for many Aussie travellers over the past five weeks with flights in and out of the popular holiday spot cancelled.
So what happens when your flight is delayed, and what about your accommodation ? Here’s what you need to know.
FLIGHTS
Both Jetstar and Virgin deemed the route unsafe to fly in consultation with their experts, meaning hundreds of Aussies were left stranded.
Most airlines will re-book passengers in available seats on upcoming flights or schedule additional flights to help clear the backlog.
With airlines now given the all clear to fly, Jetstar says it has scheduled up to 30 additional flights between now and Friday to help get customers on their way.
“In these types of events, we always look to adjust our schedule so that we can free up aircraft to operate additional services or swap larger capacity aircraft such our Boeing 787 Dreamliner to operate flights instead of smaller planes where possible,” said a Jetstar spokesperson.
However, additional flights are only possible if planes and crew are available to fly.
Customers are placed on flights according to priority with those who have been delayed the longest and those with extenuating circumstances the first to be allocated a flight.
A Jetstar plane bound for Bali was grounded at Adelaide airport. Picture: Bianca De Marchi. Source: News Corp Australia
“Qantas is also helping us get customers to their final destination after they reach Australia if their flight from Bali does not take them to their home city,” said a Jetstar spokesperson.
There are other options, however. You can choose to delay your travel or choose a different destination as a result of the cancellations.
“Jetstar is offering customers with bookings to Bali the option to change their holiday destination to any destination on its network. Jetstar will waive flight change fees for any customers with a valid booking to Bali between 8 July and 28 August, who wish to change their holiday destination. Fare differences may apply,” says the Jetstar website .
ACCOMMODATION
It’s not only flights that are affected, your accommodation the other end is too. So what can you do? It all comes down to travel insurance according to Tom Walley, Head of Flight Centre Australia.
“The right travel insurance policy will ensure you are covered for your lost accommodation, which means your travel agent can work with you to extend or re-book your accommodation in Bali.
“The same goes for flights. The benefit of booking with a travel agent is that we’re focused on exploring alternative options to get you on your way asap and pending your travel insurance coverage, we can even re-book you with another carrier,” he told Escape .
A flight board bears bad news for passengers waiting at the airport in Bali. AP Photo/Firdia Lisnawati. Source: AP
TRAVEL INSURANCE
So what do you need to know about travel insurance, besides making sure that you have it?
Michelle Hutchison, Money Expert at comparison website finder.com.au says it is crucial to take out travel insurance during the initial planning of your trip.
As travellers will find out, it’s too late to take out cover for an event that’s already occurred, since it’s viewed as a forseen event.
“This means that even if you apply for cover now, you could be hard pressed to have any altercations en-route to Bali compensated, as it’s not unforeseen,” says Hutchison.
Ms Hutchison says that the industry estimates that 30 per cent of the 16,000 Aussie travellers jetsetting to Bali on a weekly basis aren’t taking out cover, leaving them out of pocket.
“While you should be issued a new flight from your airline, if you can’t fly on the new allocated date or you’ve been hit with fees from changing plans at your destination end, this is when travel insurance will come in handy (if you took it out before the ash cloud issue).
“One of the best-case scenarios for Aussies caught in a current Bali-travel mishap is to retain all your receipts and documents. It’s a last-ditch effort, but the fine print may end up giving your situation a silver lining. And next time, don’t wait for a disaster to get cover for your travel.”
For now the airlines and Aussies heading to and from Bali hope the worst is over.
